--- title: "Genuary 2026" description: "Generative Art for January 2026" date: "2026-02-01" categories: [Python] image: "Jan_01.svg" execute: eval: false jupyter: python3 --- I participated in [Genuary](https://genuary.art/) 2026 this year. I went with one prompt a week and kept the files [here](https://github.com/WilliamTylerBradley/genuary2026). I also focused on using SVGs for this run and kept all of them 100x100.

JAN. 1: One color, one shape

I used an arrow that followed the gradient from OpenSimplex noise. I created a base shape, copied it on to a hexagonal grid, then used transformations to rotate them. ![Jan_01](Jan_01.svg){width=80%}

JAN. 10: Polar coordinates

This is a random walk through polar coordinates. The arc length is consistent so the change in theta is different based on the radius. ![Jan_10](Jan_10.svg){width=80%}

JAN. 17: Wallpaper group

This is based on a herringbone pattern for group pg. The colors are based on RGB and modulo on row number. ![Jan_17](Jan_17.svg){width=80%}

JAN. 27: Lifeform. A shape or structure that behaves as if itâ€™s alive or growing.

Based on vegetation. This work uses cubic curves. ![Jan_27](Jan_27.svg){width=80%}

JAN. 29: Genetic evolution and mutation.

This has three polygons that grow until one reaches the outer boundary. This is my least favorite out of all of them. ![Jan_29](Jan_29.svg){width=80%}
